awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying Heat/Mass Structure and Fluxes Through the Full Thickness of Greenland?s Percolation Zone
awd_abstract_narration:
Much of the snow that covers the Greenland Ice Sheet experiences melting during summer months. This meltwater percolates and refreezes within the underlying snow. Over time, this altered snow, which is referred to as firn, can reach to depths of 100 meters. These changes in firn structure consequently alter the heat flow within the ice, and between the ice sheet and the atmosphere. As yet however, the full structure of the firn layer is unclear as observations have been limited to shallow depths. To address this important lack of understanding, the investigators propose a field study focused on drilling a number of deep ice cores, with the goal of characterizing the thermal and physical properties of the deep firn ice. This information is essential to predicting ice sheet changes in volume and sea level rise. The project involves graduate and undergraduate students, an early career scientist, and includes public outreach activities.

The project will test the hypothesis that the deep firn in the low elevation regions of Greenland experience densification governed by water infiltration/refreezing and thermally enhanced compaction. The project will develop a novel hot water drilling system to quickly penetrate 100 meters through the technically challenging conditions of intermixed cold and wet firn. In situ data collection will include digital temperature strings, video and core logging, and an instrumented drill stem. This work will yield a full-depth characterization of firn thickness, density, permeability, and thermal status. Moreover, drilling conducted a decade earlier in the region will permit the investigators to assess changes in firn properties over time. Ultimately, understanding meltwater retention and refreezing processes across Greenland?s accumulation area is essential for advancing prediction of ice sheet volume change,flow dynamics, and sea level change. The project will provide field and laboratory research experiences impacting a large number of undergraduate and graduate students. The project will support a newly funded young investigator, and will include outreach activities targeting the general public and middle school students in Greenland and Western Montana.

por.por_cntn:
About 90% of the Greenland Ice Sheet is covered by a layer of snow and aging snow (called firn) which is transitioning through compaction to become glacier ice. As the Arctic warms, the average duration and intensity of melting of the Greenland Ice Sheet?s surface is increasing, resulting in more liquid water infiltrating into the thick firn layer. The resulting transformation of the thermal and density structure of the firn layer has uncertain implications for forthcoming infiltration. The objective of this project was to directly measure the deep thermal and density structure of the firn layer within network of 30 and 100 m deep firn cores and boreholes.

To achieve the overarching project goals we developed a hot water drill system capable of quickly drilling to 100 m depth in the firn layer. Instrumentation on the drill stem allowed the drill penetration process to provided structural information about the firn. Firn cores drilled to 30 meters depth provided data on firn density and ice layers formed by refreezing of liquid water. An instrumentation network was installed to measure deep firn temperature time series at six sites along a ~50 km elevation transect. Unfortunately, restrictions on access to remote field sites in Greenland during the Covid pandemic prevented servicing and data collection from the instrumentation network, resulting in a limited dataset. The research directions of the PIs and students working on the project were redirected to address project objectives by other investigations. Nevertheless, project objectives were achieved through various activities.

Student training and outreach activities resulting from this project include:

? 3 M.S. thesis projects
? 1 PhD dissertation
? 3 undergraduate senior thesis projects
? Enhancement of two undergraduate and one graduate level courses.
? Community outreach activities to K-12 school children.

Scientific research activities:
Analyses were performed on data collected by this project, numerical simulations, and new analyses of other existing datasets. Six peer reviewed publications addressed the following topics.

? Horizontal advection of firn.
Numerical simulations demonstrated the impacts of horizontal advection on the development of firn density, temperature, and the stratigraphy of melt features through the Greenland ice sheet percolation zone. The horizontal advection process tends to increase the pore close-off depth, reduce the heat content, and decrease the frequency of melt features with depth by emplacing firn sourced from higher locations under increasingly warm and melt-affected surface conditions.

? Physical limitations of infiltration.
In situ experiments were used to develop a grain-scale model to investigate constrains on the relative importance of firn density, temperature, and grain/pore size inhibiting wetting front migration. Results imply that deep infiltration, including that which leads to firn aquifer formation, does not have access to all available firn pore space.

? Spatial coherence of ice layering.
A dynamic time warping (DTW) algorithm for time series alignment was used to investigate and quantify the heterogeneous impact of melt processes on nine closely spaced (within 50 m) firn core density profiles. Ice layers were classified into four depth zones of mass redistribution. Roughly 75% of density measurements from each core do not align with an age model that assumes no mass redistribution of meltwater, indicating the pervasive impact of melt processes.

? Cold season rainfall.
We document changes to Greenland?s firn column due to a four-day cold-season warm/rain event. The amount of liquid water refrozen in the firn column was ~20-100% of the prior summer demonstrating the potential impact of extreme weather events on the ice sheet?s evolution and runoff characteristics.

? Firn temperature gradients.
Field measurements document an elevation gradient in the penetration of summer heat into the firn layer resulting from conductive heat, latent heat, and increases in thermal conductivity of the overall firn column at higher density. The deep firn temperature gradient below (20 m) steepened over twofold along a 50 km transect, implying greater heat flux from the firn layer to the deep ice at lower elevation.
